text: Our hero, JAY CAVENDISH lies on a blanket, a colt six-sho gun in his hand, and looks up to a sky full of stars He begins his nightly recital, naming each constellation

Pegasus, The Great Bear, The Dragon, Andromeda JAY is sixteen, skinny, dark hair and dark eyes, handsome an other-worldly way He is about to sleep fully clothed, and what fine clothes they are - an exquisitely tailored three piece suit and f leather boots JAY lifts his gun up and points to the night sky and pret to shoot He makes a soft sound on each ‘pretend shot’ and a star appears and forms Orion
Orion’s Belt JAY lowers his gun and smiles as he remembers the love of life, ROSE ROSS
ROSE ROSS, beautiful, dressed in peasant clothes, sits on of JAY, smiles
JAY stows away his gun, tucks his wallet into his inside pocket, rolls onto his side, shuts his eyes and falls asl
Next day, first light, dawn chorus, JAY rolls up his blan and grabs his duffle bag

JAY sits on his horse. His horse is laden with many bags, cases, blankets, boxes JAY pulls out a small wooden box and lifts lid to reveal compass JAY rides off in the direction - WEST He rides awkwardly though the trees, holding the compass aloft

JAY rides out of the forest into an open grass prairie The sun now beats down Strange structures appear. Dotted across the prairie, bod wrapped in cloth lie on stilts facing the sky A Native burial ground, a happy hunting ground The stilts are adorned with feathers and beads JAY weaves through the structures and past a group of nat women sitting, preparing dead bodies of men wrapped in cl JAY rides past. The women ignore him

Into the forest A line of native women and children pass JAY The final native, carrying a baby looks at JAY as he pass JAY rides on, bringing his compass out again and continui West  JAY has another flashing memory of ROSE and their time together in Scotland

A strong wind blowing, a heathery landscape and beyond a rough sea Rose stands on top of a small rock formation and lifts he arms causing her shawl to flap in the wind JAY sits next to her ROSE turns and smiles at JAY, then leaps from the small r and runs down the hill

JAY rides into a cloud of dense smoke The forest air becomes ‘foggy’ until JAY is but a faint silhouette He and his pony begin to cough JAY covers his mouth with cloth The air is thick with ash Black jagged shapes- burnt stumps of trees emerge from th grey Now only shades of grey

I was drifting west when I picked up his trail - deep in Colorado Territory - A jack-rabbit in a den of wolves, fortunate to be alive (The voice over is an older man than JAY, with an Irish accent - Later we will meet the man who owns this voice) JAY, now walking his horse, has covered his mouth with a handkerchief JAY is covered head to toe in gray ash, and so is his hor JAY enters a clearing Remains of tee-pee frames and tree stumps smoulder black smoke  This was a Native camp, freshly razed to the ground JAY leads his horse through the remains No bodies. The dead removed Another forest clearing A distant gun shot startles JAY and his horse JAY stops Another gun shot Then another JAY walks slowly from his horse More gunshots Branches snap under foot from yonder, the sound of someon running towards JAY A muscular young NATIVE MAN sprints from the brush and sk to a halt in front of JAY Bare chested, coated in blood Standing proud and waiting as if preparing to die by JAY' hand JAY ash-grey The young MAN blood-red For a moment they study each other’s strangeness Another gunshot and the NATIVE MAN looks around then bolt past JAY More rustling and twig snapping as THREE MEN dressed as U soldiers emerge TWO BOYS in dirty old Yankee uniforms and an OLDER MAN in officer’s outfit Guns are quickly raised to point at JAY
Arms abroad boy! JAY raises his arms up
Red skinned or white? The coat of ash covering JAY the source of confusion
Sir. I am British.. Scottish The officer barks orders to his two protegés

Catch the savage The two YOUNG SOLDIERS run off into the woods JAY and the OFFICER stare at each other for a BEAT Two muffled gunshots then silence The OFFICER smiles, thinking the NATIVE has been killed
I am Jay Cavendish, Son of Lady Cavendish OFFICER lowers his rifle and walks towards JAY

We're all Sons of Bitches Seemingly from thin air, a figure appears behind the OFFI and cocks his gun by the OFFICER'S ear, while taking the OFFICER’s gun in one smooth action This is SILAS SELLECK Mid thirties, lean, fit SILAS is dirt ingrained, only his eyes are clean SILAS looks WILD, yet.. His movements are skillful, economic, fast, his posture confident, capable and in control to the point of blasé Succinct in words and action
A grave play, boy JAY draws his gun and points it at SILAS
Sir. Lower your pistol SILAS sighs, then slowly circles round continuing to hold gun to the OFFICER’S head, and moves towards JAY

Hey ! SILAS moves up to JAY, continuing to point the gun at the OFFICER, and snatches JAY’S gun from him  6. SILAS points JAY'S gun at the OFFICER and pulls the trigg but the gun is empty and clicks The officer smiles at this, but quick as a flash, SILAS raises his own gun up and shoots the officer between the Dead before he hits the ground Without taking his eyes off the officer, SILAS throws JAY gun him
Clean it. Oil it JAY fumbles the catch SILAS walks over to the officer and crouches down Pulls out a large knife and cuts a pouch from the officer belt JAY looks on
What do you want? SILAS checks the contents of the pouch and stuffs it into belt
He was an Officer SILAS looks through the man’s pockets and finds a tin

Wearin’ a dress don’t make her a lady SILAS pockets the tin SILAS (CONT’D) They ain’t soldiers. Least no more. Indian slayers SILAS moves round and removes the OFFICER’s boots and addresses JAY without looking up
Keep headin’ West solo you'll be dead by dawn. How you made it this far is a miracle
I take care of myself
Sure kid. You need chaperonin’ and I’m a chaperone SILAS gets up and walks towards JAY JAY takes a step back, still holding his gun SILAS walks past JAY and towards JAY’s horse
Safer to travel with a killer?
That's right SILAS checks out JAY’s laden horse. Too many bags and cas for a small pony to carry SILAS begins to cut the bags free
First lets save your pony’s life SILAS cuts a case free and it drops to the ground

I counted a dozen of them bastards attack them Indians back there. Minus three that leaves.. too many JAY’s turns and looks into the woods in all directions SILAS, now down on his knees, rakes through JAY’s case. Tosses out a kettle, throws a useless box over his should Tosses boots and a shirt Finds a book, looks at the cover and holds it up to JAY JAY reads the title
‘Ho for the West. A traveller and Emigrants Hand-book SILAS keeps looking at JAY
To Canada and the North West States of America’... SILAS keeps staring
..-By Edward Hepple Hall SILAS throws the book over his shoulder  10
Well ho for the West SILAS casts the whole case aside, gets up and walks towar
Dollars. Fifty now, fifty when we split JAY turns his back to SILAS and fumbles in his wallet Turns back around and hands SILAS fifty dollars
Until we reach a forest called Silverghost SILAS snatches the cash, counts it, and walks off
Lets drift JAY runs around and picks up his ‘Ho for the West’ book, grabs the reins of his pony and follows SILAS
JAY rides behind SILAS through the forest, brushing the remaining ash from his hair and suit JAY trots up level with SILAS
What’s your name? SILAS snaps
Drop back, single file JAY drops back behind SILAS SILAS leads, JAY follows, staying single file as instruct
Why you headin’ West? SILAS does not respond
You care not why I’m headed West? No response  11
There was an accident - My girl and her father fled from Scotland, settled out West. It was all my fault
Take a hint kid?
We love each other
Sure you do, kid They ride on in silence Close up of JAY, sound of waves breaking - Another memory Rose
Moody grey sky Large waves crash onto a sandy beach, the beach becomes s dunes JAY stands at the top of a large dune ROSE, standing at the bottom, shouts up to JAY
JAY! A thousand ways to die, choose one JAY strikes a thinking pose

Bow and arrow She pulls a pretend arrow from a pretend quiver and prete fires it at JAY JAY pretends to be shot in the heart and falls dramatical He rolls down the dune to ROSE’s feet and lays still, fac up, eyes shut, tongue out ROSE jumps on top of JAY and smiles. (This is the moment saw in JAY’s first memory at the beginning of the film) JAY'S eyes are shut, ROSE places her hand on JAY’S chest leans in, her ear to his chest, continuing the charade by checking if JAY is breathing JAY places his hands on Rose’s hands  12 10. ROSE smiles, but pulls away, breaking the moment, pushes JAY'’s head to the side
Silly boy ROSE jumps up Runs up the dune, shouting
My turn JAY looks up to the sky

JAY rides behind SILAS Low light, long shadows Distant echo of a pretty acapella song emanates from the trees ahead JAY head slumped, the music stirs him from his daydream Three AFRICAN MEN, clothed in dusty ragged Union soldier suits, sit in a circle, one in a makeshift wooden wheel chair, one on crutches, wounds from the Civil War They sing a beautiful Congolese song. (They’re Congolese) SILAS rides straight past, JAY stops to listen SILAS stops, grumps, spits, and turns SILAS wolf whistles, JAY ignores SILAS shakes his head, turns and trots off The band smile, singing for the pleasure of singing. The ends and the man on crutches looks up at JAY
Did you enjoy our music? JAY answers in French
Yes. I enjoyed the song very much
It’s a song about love  13 14 11.
Love is universal, like death JAY nods to the band, who start playing again, and rides after SILAS
The Sun bakes the land. JAY and SILAS keep heading WEST

The kid was a wonder. He saw things differently. To him we were ina land of hope and good will. The way I saw it, kick over any rock and most likely a desperado would crawl out and knife you right in the heart if there was a dollar in it

A rag-tag posse of seven men and a woman, all on horsebac form a row and watch a distant SILAS and JAY cross the ri bed The posse are all distinct and characterful A Chinese man, ‘TATOO MAN’, in traditional Chinese garb, black hair and beard A Dylan-esque musician ‘THE MINSTREL’ with a feather in h hat and a banjo strapped to his back A Mexican woman, poncho and braids ‘MARIMACHO’ A wizened ol’ gold-digger type. Large soft hat, silver be this is SKELLY A good looking young kid, arrogant expression. This is ‘T KID’ A crazy looking goggle-eyed man, aged beyond his years by drugs and liquor. This is PEYOTE JOE The gang leader - PAYNE - Massive fur coat, cigar PAYNE watches SILAS and JAY with added interest and a kno half smile

SILAS and JAY have set up camp JAY sits on his blanket, SILAS up against a tree JAY throws rabbit bones from his plate into the trees SILAS sees this JAY lies back and looks at the stars while SILAS is filli bullet shells with fresh gunpowder
Same stars. Same moon SILAS ignores him
One day we'll be wandering ‘round that moon SILAS ignores
They'll build a railroad SILAS keeps ignoring
But a railroad up and down the ways. A railroad to the moon. And when we get there, first thing we'll do is hunt the natives down SILAS bites
No Indians on the moon JAY sits up
No. The natives of the moon. The moon people SILAS flashes JAY an incredulous look JAY lies back down, points to stars and begins his nightl recital
Pegasus, The Great Bear, The Dragon A crackle of sticks under foot in the darkness
Shh!  16 17 13. JAY shuts up SILAS gets up, picks up rifle JAY sits up SILAS soldier-like, cocks rifle, moves off into the woods JAY about to follow

Sit down JAY obeys, and now feels more alone than he did when he w alone.. JAY brings his gun out and stays still for a BEAT SILAS emerges from the shadows SILAS picks up Jay’s rabbit bones and throws them into th fire SILAS (CONT’D) This is the last time I’m gonna clean up your shit SILAS sits back up against the tree, places his rifle on lap and covers himself with a blanket SILAS’ way of saying good night JAY looks around Wolves howl JAY lies back and stares up at the moon and stars and slo and quietly un-cocks his gun
Horse clops on wood as SILAS and JAY ride across a ricket bridge

Mid day sun beating down, the familiar red-tailed hawk screech SILAS and JAY walk their horses up through a yellowish ro canyon The canyon narrows forming a pass a couple of yards wide  18 14. A buffalo has got trapped in the narrow gap and died ther It has been picked clean of meat down to its gleaming whi bones The skeleton blocks the route WEST JAY and SILAS approach
Must have been winter when Rose passed through here They begin to pull the heavy bones from between the rock JAY lifts up the skull
What’s she like? JAY perks up
She’s a beauty. And.. She does not waste words. They tumble out, wit following wisdom
You haven't bedded her, have you SILAS laughs JAY shakes his head SILAS gestures to the buffalo rib cage
Grab that end
You're a brute They lift the rib cage together and dump clear of the tra and walk the horses through the pass
SILAS swigs from a water bottle and tosses it back to JAY
A trading post up ahead. We can dine at a table while sitting on a chair

SILAS and JAY ride up to the trading post A small one room wooden shack, a veranda running along th front There is a horse tied up out front. It is jet black, shin and muscular SILAS looks at the horse as he dismounts

Tie the horses round back JAY leads the horses round the side of the building SILAS reaches the veranda Left of the trading post door there is a makeshift notice board fixed to the wall SILAS turns to make sure JAY is out of sight, then checks the notices Amongst a number of wanted posters of grim faced outlaws, wanted poster for ROSE ROSS and JOHN ROSS Beneath a drawing of JOHN and ROSE, a crude likeness, rea JOHN ROSS and his daughter ROSE ROSS - ‘WANTED FOR MURDER REWARD $2000 DEAD OR ALIVE’ SILAS rips the poster from the board

Everyone knew about the bounty, except Jay. He was leading me right to it. The trading post door swings open and a man exits. SILAS turns his head This is VICTOR THE HAWK - He is wearing a priest’s get-up white dog collar, black suit, black hat, perfectly groome Everything about this man is long, sharp and clean VICTOR carries a long black case, about the length of a l rifle and probably containing a large rifle For a brief moment he stops and looks at SILAS. A beat of recognition between both men. SILAS looks down at the cas VICTOR knows he knows.. A bounty hunter can smell another bounty hunter VICTOR tips his hat, walks off, mounts horse, rides off  20 16.
There were few of us left, men beyond the law SILAS walks into the trading post
But the most dangerous were the last to fall JAY saunters around the corner, sees VICTOR riding off

Inside the trading post is dark and dusty, shelves on all sides are filled with necessities. Native blankets, furs, buffalo skins, pots, pans, coffee, ammunition, saddle bag suits, boots, shovels, pan handles, horse shoes, bags of and corn, jars of honey and rolls of string. (See p. 168 Little house in the big woods) A counter runs along the back of the shop. In front of th counter and to the left, two small wooden tables, four chairs. To the right, more shelves piled high, and an entrance to a small changing room covered by a large Nati rug An OLD MAN stands behind the counter SILAS walks up to the counter, strikes a match on the sid lights his cigar
May I ask you to place your iron on the counter while you browse? SILAS obliges, then wanders round the room checking the s JAY enters, closing the door behind him
We'll be dining JAY wanders over to some clothes on a rail
May I try on a suit?
Sure, be my guest JAY crosses the room and enters the small changing room, pulls closed the native blanket curtain  17. SILAS sits down at a table in the opposite corner of the
There is a filthy mirror on the wall JAY wipes it clean with his sleeve Looks at his disheveled reflection
The STOREKEEPER picks up a couple of glasses and a bottle whisky and approaches SILAS
Whisky? SILAS shakes his head
You got meat?
I got condemned bacon. Traded it for bullets. Both’11 kill you pretty quick SILAS shakes his head, pulls out the wanted poster, unfol
There is a comb on a string next to the mirror JAY picks it up but sees it is full of old hair and drops JAY brings his gun out from his inside pocket and lays it a stool
SILAS studies the wanted poster
JAY tries on the suit jacket, notices a hole right by his heart The hole was made by a bullet and around the hole, dried crusts of the blood of the previous owner JAY sticks his finger in the hole

The door swings open A man and a woman enter  18. They are Swedish, a young couple, clothes dusty from trav They move nervously, jittery, eyes showing desperation. T man JOHAN is skinny. (Ref: Shame by Bergman) The woman MARIA, skinny but wears so many clothes and rag and shawls that she looks larger JOHAN notices SILAS and looks at MARIA with concern SILAS keeps his eye on the man as he nervously approaches the counter JOHAN points to a blanket on a high shelf behind the storekeeper
Blanket please
Blanket, ha.. The storekeeper climbs on a stool and reaches up for a blanket While his back is turned, MARIA swipes some items and pla them in her bundle of bosom
Ma’am, you have to purchase items before baggin’ ‘em. That's how we do it here in America SILAS alert MARIA throws a sharp stare at JOHAN
Johan! SILAS smells trouble JOHAN brings a colt pistol from his inside jacket pocket points it at the head of the storekeeper The storekeeper raises his hands and takes a step back
S..s..sorry.. Money .. Pl..please
Jay stock still, listens  19.
Now looky here, you realise if I give you money, here’s the only place round where you can spend it
Johan! JOHAN cocks the gun SILAS and JAY both frozen in their respective places
Money! ! MARIA goads JOHAN

Johan! What must be done! JOHAN follows his wive’s orders and smacks the storekeepe the face with the butt of his pistol The storekeeper falls out of sight and rises with a shotg and shoots JOHAN point black in the chest JOHAN is flung backwards against a post and falls down de MARIA in shock, pulls out a small pistol and fires it at STOREKEEPER, who falls down dead behind the store counter MARIA is now hysterical MARIA (CONT’D) Johan!! She stops breathing, in shock, turns and points her gun a
SILAS, unarmed, stares at MARIA
Breathe
JAY picks up his gun from the stool
Breathe... In.. And out
Money!  20.
JAY is listening to SILAS and breathing in and out in tim SILAS is actually talking to JAY, to calm him and direct and its working
Money! !
Breathe in.. And out
JAY breathers in and out
Money !
Breathe JAY walks out of the changing room, directly behind MARIA and MARIA directly in front of SILAS
Money !

In.. And out And on “out” JAY pulls the trigger, shooting MARIA in the back, MARIA falls down dead JAY frozen to the spot, stares at the dead body, drops hi gun SILAS breathes a sigh of relief, then gets up fast SILAS (CONT’D) Grab some provisions He turns to see JAY still frozen to the spot, staring at woman
Jay! SILAS collects useful items, tins of food, ammo, oil JAY collects useless items, chocolate, honey etc  21 22 21.

JAY exits the trading post into the bright daylight He stops abruptly Two CHILDREN stand, hold hands, waiting for their parents A GIRL aged ten, a little BOY aged six, blond, sweet SILAS exits and sees the kids

shit.. SILAS shuts the door before the kids can see the fate of their parents JAY approaches the kids SILAS goes to fetch the horses JAY lays all the stuff he’s gathered from the shop at the feet of the kids then just stares at them
Why are you sad? SILAS reappears with the horses
Dry your eyes kid - let’s drift JAY begrudgingly turns, mounts and they ride off, leaving kids to their fate

JAY and SILAS ride in silence SILAS begins to whistle a tune - Yankee doodle.. JAY snarls, thinking SILAS is happy CUTTING TO SILAS, we see he is putting on a brave face, holding back a tear SILAS looks down at his hand His hand is shaking violently. SILAS clenches into a fist
We could have taken them in SILAS growls  23 24 22.
In where?
JAY lies awake and we enter his thoughts, his memories

Single room crofters cottage, basic but homely. Hard pack earth floor, small kitchen table, fireplace for heat and cooking. Bunk beds down one wall, a tiny window the only light source JAY and ROSE sit side by side on the bed JAY looks mournful, ROSE happy ROSE makes a gun shape with her hand and pretends to shoo JAY in the heart, and smiles JAY makes an effort to smile back
How do you feel.. About me ROSE turns serious
You’re the little brother I never had JAY gutted, almost resentful
You don’t mean that. That’s not what you mean JAY looks at ROSE, that same longing look from the dunes
I’m sorry my Romeo, but these violent delights.. ROSE grabs JAY and tickles him
Have violent ends.. JAY stands up and turns to ROSE  23.
What choice do you have? A farmer, a fisherman! ROSE’s smile wiped
Best you leave now, Jay ROSE hears a gate shut outside and springs into nervous action, looking around for a place to hide JAY He should not be in here
No violence, we need protection, crofters rights.. The voices of ROSE’s father, JOHN ROSS, and another MAN approaching the door, ROSE panics
Under the bed JAY shakes his head

No ROSE does not take no for an answer and pulls JAY under t bed JAY crawls under, turns himself around to look out ROSE’s father JOHN ROSS is a big man He is with a smaller man named CALUM, a friend of the fam
Daddy
Rose
Hello Rose JAY watches from under the bed
LATER - More men enter the room, JAY still stuck under th bed
JAY stirs SILAS is up and taking a piss He scratches his ass with the barrel of his gun JAY turns over and drifts back into..

The room is now full of people and JAY is still trapped u the bed Two WOMEN sit knitting in the corner of the room Three MEN play musical instruments JOHN ROSS holds court at the table, telling a wild tale ROSE stands by the bed, looks down at JAY and they exchan quick smile Another man enters the crowded room and lays a lobster cr down by the bed, right in front of JAY Inside the creel is a cat Another MAN recites a Gaelic poem The atmosphere cuts dead when.. Another MAN enters, flanked by two BURLY MEN. This is RUP JAY’s uncle and the landowner This wipes the smile from ROSE The rest of the room looks nervous JAY shrinks to the dark back wall of the bed
Lord Cavendish! May I help you?
I’ve come for my nephew Rupert looks under the bed and finds JAY
You should not be in here. These people are peasants
SILAS finished pissing, returns to his camp bed
RUPERT drags JAY by the scruff of the neck out the door o the Ross cottage, followed by JOHN ROSS, ROSE, and some o the other MEN JAY breaks free of RUPERT and walks to ROSE’s side
I’m with Rose now This is news to ROSE, news to ROSE’s FATHER, and news to

RUPERT slowly approaches JAY He lifts a hand to slap JAY, but instead slaps ROSE This enrages JOHN ROSS, he grabs RUPERT and throws him backwards to the ground A thud as RUPERT smacks his head on a rock The rock drips with blood and RUPERT looks all but dead JAY runs off into the dark of night

JAY turns to look at SILAS, fast asleep JAY quietly and slowly rises up and rolls up his blanket the time watching SILAS SILAS appears not to waken JAY glances round camp to check he’s not left anything SILAS opens his eyes and looks at JAY, then shuts his eye again JAY creeps out of camp
JAY rides, morning has broken JAY is out of the forest and now on the vast flat plains Southern Colorado  31 32 26.
Noon sun, JAY sleeps as he rides WEST

Sun low, shadows long JAY stops In the distance a horse and wagon, a camp fire, one MAN A DOG trots over from the camp towards JAY, a little wolf like scrubby mongrel Pants happily, sits looking at JAY JAY decides to approach the camp, slowly The MAN now stands, rifle in hand JAY stops again - within earshot of the MAN The MAN places his gun down and waves This man is WERNER. He has a kind, intelligent face, midd aged, stubbly beard, (looks and sounds like Werner Herzog
Good evening! JAY smiles at WERNER
I come in peace WERNER smiles back
My ears hear your music! WERNER beckons JAY to join him
Come, come JAY dismounts WERNER giddily runs to the back of his wagon and pulls ou second chair, places it next to his little fire
Sit. I have coffee WERNER sits opposite , happy to have the company JAY sits, looks down at a journal next to WERNER  27.
You a writer?

Perhaps WERNER holds up his journal. A long title fills the front cover He reads the title slowly WERNER (CONT’D) I am “Recording the decline of aboriginal tribes - their customs, culture and habits - In the hope of preventing their extinction or conversion to Christianity” - The title of my account. Too long?
Perhaps WERNER lays the book down
So now. East. What news? JAY looks East
Violence and suffering, and West? Werner looks West
Dreams and toil
I passed though burnt remains of an Indian camp WERNER saddened, picks up his journal

This is dreadful news A race extinct, their culture banished, their places re-named, only then will they be viewed with selective nostalgia, mythologised and romanticised in the safe guise of art.. And literature Werner holds up the journal on ‘literature’
This is a new world for us, also for them  33 28. Sun setting, light fading WERNER gets up walks towards his wagon
You must be hungry He roots around the back of the wagon. He has all sorts i there, about four saddles, many bags, much junk He finds some bread and brings it to JAY
‘Til now my sole company’s been a brute
Sorry to hear this
I escaped WERNER hands JAY bread, sits back down JAY takes a bite of bread
Thank you
Camp surrounded by blackness JAY and WERNER lit by the fire, the back of WERNER’s wago lit by a lamp
I killed a woman yesterday
Part and parcel WERNER warms his hands by the flames
You care not to share your company with a murderer?
I'd be a lonely man if I did WERNER shakes his head WERNER (CONT’D) I am no Judge nor Father  34 29. WERNER now looks devilish in the light of the flames
In a short time, this will be a long time ago Distant wolves howl WERNER picks up his rifle and stands up
Camp here. Blanket? JAY nods
Thank you WERNER returns to the back of the wagon and pulls out a blanket, brings it to JAY
I shall dream up some advice and in the morning dish it up with fresh eggs
What’s your name?
Werner
I’m Jay. Good night and thank you Werner WERNER nods, turns, climbs into the back of his wagon and shuts the doors JAY alone under the vast starry sky

When JAY wakes up in the morning he is more than alone ag WERNER has gone, and taken JAY’S horse, all JAY’s possessions, clothes, everything JAY sits up in his all-in-one long Johns and looks around Stands up Looks down, a chicken egg sits on a note Picks up the egg, the note flaps along the ground JAY runs after it, grabs the note and reads  35 36 30. NOTE- “West” and a arrow JAY looks at the arrow west and turns round with the pape his hand before realising the joke of having an arrow wes drawn. . JAY throws the note to the wind, angry and amused in equa measure Drapes the blanket over his shoulder Tries to peal the shell from the egg Picks up a small stone to chip the egg shell, and the egg breaks, but it is raw, not boiled, and drips to the groun
JAY wanders across the vast windy plain

JAY's now staggering, hungry, tired He spots a few mushrooms sprouting from the dust He throws himself to the ground dramatically, like he has eaten for a week Sniffs the mushrooms The wind blowing hard, has prevented JAY from hearing a h approach from behind him The shadow of the man on the horse slides over JAY JAY turns round to see SILAS and he has JAY'S horse in to possessions intact
You can eat those SILAS nods at the mushrooms
Eat enough of them, you can fly to Rose JAY looks at his horse and looks at SILAS
You kill Werner? SILAS takes time to shape his answer  37 38 31.
No. No reason JAY goes to his horse and brings out his wallet from his Pulls out the rest of his money and holds it out to SILAS
This is all the money I have. Get me there in one piece SILAS takes the money
Sure kid SILAS hands JAY a biscuit
Have a biscuit JAY munches it fast
SILAS and JAY ride across the plain towards a forest
SILAS and JAY have stopped and are looking at something i the woods
That's a shame

Is it? We see what they are looking at A tree has been chopped down and fallen on top of the fel completely squishing him His arms stick out as if a cartoon, his flesh long gone, clothes disintegrating, his skeleton hand still grasps th axe
No. No, it's not Both men smile at each other  39 40 32. Nothing like someone else's misfortune to bond a friendsh
Charles Darwin talks of ‘evolution by natural selection’
For our sake lets hope he's wrong
The men ride on, SILAS is riding in front of JAY JAY is singing

My lord is hunting he has gone, hounds and hawks with him are none, beyond Silverghost lies his game, Rose Ross is her name SILAS puts on his jacket for no reason other than to brin out the ROSE and JOHN ROSS Wanted poster SILAS checks that JAY is not looking (JAY is not) SILAS looks at the drawing of ROSE, flips it over and loo at the $2000, flips it back to ROSE, then pockets it

A pretty clearing in the forest, dappled light through tr a gentle trickling stream, a campfire crackling, logs lai out for sitting, a kettle boiling JAY sits on a log SILAS approaches him while sharpening a large hunting kni SILAS walks behind JAY holding the knife up

The knife's got to be as sharp as a razor JAY's face has been lathered up with soap, the irony is J is still too young for even the hint of stubble SILAS (CONT’D) You hold the knife flush, against the skin SILAS holds the knife flush against JAY's throat  33. SILAS (CONT’D) And it's a scraping motion against the grain, not a slicing motion SILAS scrapes the knife up the side of JAYS face and wipe the soap on a cloth over his shoulder
Like so.. We gotta make you presentable for her JAY smiles at this
I know why you need my help SILAS pauses..
Oh yeah?
Yeah - You’re lonely. You’re a lonely man The truth throws SILAS for a beat
Sure kid
Sure kid. Lets drift. The silent, lonely drifter SILAS continues to shave JAY
You’re a lonely, lonely man
No need to concern over me SILAS places the blade on JAY JAY flinches
Hold still
All I’m saying is.. There's more to life than just surviving
Yeah - there's dyin’. Survival ain't jus’ how to skin a jack- rabbit. (MORE )
It's knowing when to bluster and when to hush. When to take a beatin’ and when to strike
Where's your folks?
Father's in the ground in Ireland, Mother's in the ground in Canada
So what keeps you from joining them? SILAS snaps
I dunno kid, quit askin’ me shit JAY smiles
I was fine ‘til you showed up
I showed up? You showed up
Yeah well maybe I’m tired of showin’ up A distant noise like tinkling of glasses.. SILAS stops shaving JAY, half finished, and looks to the trees, brings out his gun and cocks it

You're done SILAS slowly walks across camp towards the noise, gun poi A man wanders into view - PAYNE - we remember him as the leader of the posse watching JAY and SILAS ride days back We especially remember because PAYNE wears an enormous fu coat PAYNE is a generation older than SILAS and a generation wilder PAYNE chomps on a cigar, (bigger than SILAS’s cigar) carr a couple of glasses in one hand (source of the clinking) a bottle of absinthe in the other PAYNE pauses for dramatic effect, unbothered by Silas and gun  35. PAYNE holds his hands out wide as he does a balletic turn walking into the middle of the camp Another dramatic pause, removes cigar
May I enter?
It's a free country
Try telling the natives that PAYNE playful, SILAS wary, JAY entertained
I propose a trade. A mug of coffee for the finest imported absinthe and a cigar of unrivaled quality..
We drink tea PAYNE ignores JAY PAYNE pulls out a couple of cigars from his belt, hands o to SILAS and one to JAY
One for you, young man PAYNE, SILAS, JAY, all move to the logs by the fie and si a triangle PAYNE pours three glasses of absinthe as he checks SILAS
Still not a mark on you JAY confused
You know him ? SILAS smiles
Fuck yourself Payne PAYNE smiles
I’ve tried.. Believe me I have tried PAYNE takes a swig of the tea JAY has poured him  36.
Oh.. That's damn fine coffee
It's tea PAYNE passes an absinthe to SILAS, and to JAY, stands and toasts
To bad times in the green hour SILAS downs, JAY sips
Down it boy, it's liquid joy PAYNE casually to JAY
So you headed West ? SILAS interrupts quick before JAY can answer
North They are all lying to each other and they all know it

Yeah, I’m headed .. South! The chill. I can’t stand it - Makes my joints ache PAYNE moves his finger like he's pulling an invisible tri and makes a threatening squeaky sound, moving in close to JAY, and re-fills his glass
So why north kid ? Someone special? You’re sweetheart maybe ? Now SILAS moves in close and gives JAY the ‘don’t answer’ stare PAYNE breaks the tension
Hey.. I’m teasing, I’m teasing. You must be born on a Sunday, eh? You born on a Sunday? JAY just shakes his head
You born on a Sunday?  4l 37.
I don’t know SILAS now very alert to PAYNE's line of questioning
So it's fortunate that you’re headed North because West, it's bad, big trouble, big storm coming SILAS decides to cut this quick
Easy Payne. He's just a kid
No, he's not. He's an outlaw, just like us This saddens SILAS but pleases JAY
Any-hoo! Let's drink. To friends, old.. And new They all down another absinthe, but SILAS and JAY have dr way more than PAYNE PAYNE made sure of that

An empty bottle of Absinthe on its side - lit by the moon PAYNE sits on a log watching SILAS and JAY SILAS is showing JAY how to draw and cock his gun quickly and SILAS, half-cut, is still pretty handy SILAS shows JAY how to spin his gun round his finger
Spin it! JAY tries to copy but drops the gun The nozzle lands and sticks in the dirt
That's pretty good A swaying JAY leans down and picks up the gun, the nozzle packed with mud  38.

Get that dirt out of it.. Clean it JAY tries to clean it with his cuff then looks directly d the barrel of the gun JAY stumbles over to a tree and taps the gun against the trunk The gun goes of with a loud bang and JAY drops it and fal over This amuses SILAS greatly and he celebrates by firing his gun into the air PAYNE is sitting back against a tree, his face in shadow, watching JAY and SILAS unravel PAYNE shakes his head The plan to get SILAS and JAY drunk and talking is failin now they are too drunk
I need to piss SILAS flaps his gun in the direction of the forest (same as PAYNE came from top of scene)
Away from camp! JAY wanders into the dark PAYNE waits a beat until JAY has gone Stares at SILAS
Easy see how you two crossed paths. One's a falling angel, the other's a rising devil PAYNE walks towards SILAS SILAS staggers towards PAYNE
I’m no angel As SILAS tries to step over a log, catches his foot and f hard to the ground with a thump
True PAYNE helps SILAS to his feet  42 39. The men embrace SILAS using PAYNE to balance, PAYNE holding SILAS close
You think that's a smart play - teaming up with him - quicker than trackin’ him - simpler
Ain’t no play about it
Yeah, I guess if you knew where Rose and daddy was, you’d be done babysittin’ SILAS stays quiet
Never was a bean-spiller was ya? Not sober, nor liquored up, never was SILAS stays quiet, the men still holding each other close
What you gonna do with two thousand dollars? PAYNE places both hands on SILAS’ shoulders
Come back to us SILAS loses patience, pulls out his gun, cocks it and pus the nozzle into PAYNE's belly
I’m not like you Payne PAYNE get's it, takes a step back, and another, and anoth and keeps walking backwards into the darkness
JAY is deep in the forest taking a piss, lit by the light the moon Turns and heads through the trees, seeing the flames from camp fire
Silas!  43 40.

He trips and stumbles into the camp then freezes and look about A group of ten folk sit round the fire. JAY recognises no of them (We recognise this posse. They are PAYNE's posse from the ridge) They all look up at JAY

head_text.subj: THE KID, SKELLY, PEYOTE JOE, THE MINSTREL, TATTOO MAN

text: MARIMACHO with the TWO SWEDISH KIDS from the trading post THE KID stands up, knife in hand itching to leap on JAY a cut him up
What have ye done with SILAS and
Sitting next to THE KID, SKELLY, oldest of the gang and 2 in charge after PAYNE Nudges THE KID
Back down kid, Payne needs him alive, you'll get your chance THE KID reluctantly obeys and sits back down in a huff JAY confused, not realising he's wandered the wrong way a entered the wrong camp
What have you done with the river? PEYOTE JOE, bulging crazy eyes from way too much Peyote, answers JAY with an ominous tone
They took it JAY sits down in the circle of folk, between TATTOO MAN a
The SWEDISH GIRL watches him, recognising him from the trading post JAY doesn't recognise her JAY turns to PEYOTE JOE  44 41.
Who took it?
Didn’t see their faces MARIMACHO sees the SWEDISH GIRL stare at JAY

Kid! The SWEDISH GIRL breaks her stare and obeys MARIMACHO, crawling under a blanket with her brother MARIMACHO tucks them in SKELLY, sitting next to THE KID on the opposite side of t fire to JAY, continues a conversation
All I’m sayin’ is in my day we tried to keep out o’ the papers. You youngsters tryin’ to get in em makes no sense
And all I’m sayin’, Skell, is I want folks to respec’ me. What's the point in dyin’ if nobody knows you dead. Same goes for killin’
SKELLY spits a gob of chewed tobacco into the fire and lo around at his audience and clears his throat
I partnered with a youngling once upon a time, by the name of Bill Allson. Dying to be famous, actually, killing to be famous. Come to me one time and he said..

A stereotypical Wild West street, a younger SKELLY (teeth and shaved) and another man (BILL ALLSON) BILL ALLSON is cut from the same cloth as THE KID, new generation cowboy, good-looking, cocky swagger, fame-seek The men walk and talk (SKELLY is still telling the story but the characters mou the words)  42.
“I killed thirty men and countless savages, and I still ain’t got me no wanted poster”
Where's the justice in that? I says Its a one horse town and it looks deserted, dream-like The men approach a makeshift wooden shack, operating as t town saloon

So I’m thinking, the only way to stop this kid croakin’ more innocents is to draw up a poster. Let him find it A hand draws a wanted poster - BILL ALLISON, WANTED ~$500 DEAD OR ALIVE, its a crude poster, badly drawn
SKELLY hammers up the wanted poster on the outside wall o the saloon

The next morning I put the poster outside the waterin’ hole he was drownin’ in. Wasn’t long afore he sees the poster - “BILL ALLSON, 500 DOLLARS DEAD OR ALIVE” He yells me over BILL ALLSON looking at the poster
Skelly!
And what he says chills me to the bone
What he say?
Be a thousand by tomorrow
SKELLY crosses the street towards the saloon
Next morning I go get the poster, to pin in up the next town. The poster ain’t there SKELLY looking at the bit of wall, four corners of the po remain, the poster ripped down
I hear a gun shot and a body hit dirt. I spin around and see a mean son-of-a-bitch leanin’ over a blob
All the posse captivated by SKELLY's story
I presume this bastard seen the poster, thought it real an’ gunned down Bill for the reward
SKELLY walks to the middle of the street, pulling out his shooter without breaking his stride The man leans over the blob SKELLY fires, hitting the man in the back
So I walk and I shoot, and BANG, he falls to his knees and dies The man is on his knees
JAY lost in the story
On his knees like he's prayin’ to be alive again  51 52
SKELLY'S tone now sad
As I walk towards the dear departed...
BILL ALLSON staggers out of the saloon
Bill Allson steps out the saloon across the street! Alive as you an’ I - bottle o’ whiskey in one hand, the wanted poster in the other SKELLY steps up to the kneeling dead man
I step up to the prayin’ dead man and nudge him with my boot and he falls, revealin’ a dead lump of fur and meat SKELLY kicks over the dead man, revealing a dead black be
It was a God-damned black bear Smiles and shake of heads around the camp fire
You know what Bill Allson says to me?
What he say?
He says “you jealous bastard, trying to get your own poster” PEYOTE JOE giggles THE KID does not
Bullshit MARIMACHO smiles  53 45.
That's a good ‘un Skelly Most agree with mumbles JAY rouses out of the story and the silence sobers him up He looks around the camp, now alarmed
There's been an appalling misunderstanding. I’m at the wrong camp! JAY scrambles to his feet

Good night - good riddance JAY runs off into the darkness A gentle strum of a banjo and THE MINSTREL begins to sing THE KID, now standing again, drops his knife into the dir anger (To the tune of One man went to mow)

The good Lord brings the rain.. To wash away our troubles The devil adds the lightning To show us he's still near So the good Lord sends some thunder To warn us of the devil But devil's gonna blow us all away..
JAY returns to his own camp PAYNE has long gone SILAS is swaying, drunken, deep in thought
Silas! There's people in the woods SILAS turns to JAY
You love her?
Who?  46. SILAS snaps
Rose!
Yes BEAT. SILAS sways
Then go home, kid JAY stares at SILAS, excitement becomes anger
She's mine
She's nobody's A BEAT then JAY lunges at SILAS
Fighting talk JAY tries to hit SILAS but SILAS just smothers JAY's acti as he tries to calm him
Shhh! JAY calms, sobbing SILAS lays him down on his blanket, like a baby JAY cries
You're always shushing me!

Cos you’re always running your mouth off A loud crack of thunder JAY'S gun on the ground Ants are marching into the barrel as the first drops of r hit the ground Massive thunder crack and a flash of lightning JAY out cold, we enter his absinthe fueled dreams  54 47.

A basic wooden room, walls pain'ted white, a table and ch Nothing else, looks like a stage set The only light source is a candle on the table Rose sits on a chair at the table, reading a book by the candle light Two windows on the wall behind ROSE , but instead of glas paper, semi-transparent oiled paper Slowly and theatrically lights fade up from outside, glow through paper windows JAY is slumped against the opposite wall. Rose does not s him, JAY is the sole audience to this strange ‘play’ He smiles as he sees ROSE A distant crack of thunder and SILAS enters the room from door on the right, smiles at Rose JAY stops smiling, looks confused, then upset SILAS sits at the table with ROSE and starts to read a newspaper ROSE gets up and approaches JAY (POV CAMERA), leans in an picks up.. a baby The baby is crying ROSE sits back down and rocks the baby
Jay-bird, why so sad? SILAS smiles Suddenly rain and thunder sound From somewhere (reality, not dream) we hear JAY shouting
Silas!! The lights dim on the dream scene

SILAS wakes up - (note - the audience is led to believe t was JAY's dream, it begins as JAY'S dream, as we cut back reality with SILAS waking, we may presume this is also SI dream) SILAS wakes up JAY shouting Dawn throws light on an unexpected and chaotic state of affairs Thunder crashes, lightning is flashes, heavy rain falls i sheets The river has burst its banks and the camp has become the river The water is up to SILAS’ waist as he sits upright agains tree Food, clothing, blankets, equipment, all float around the and down the river SILAS leaps up JAY looks for his gun
Silas! I can’t find my gun SILAS looks down at his now empty holster, then runs to t side of the tree where he left his rifle, now just an emp case

Son of a Bitch! PAYNE has stolen all their weapons They splash around grabbing their gear Each lightening flare reveals a fresh tableau of chaos JAY'S book ‘Ho for the West’ slowly revolves as it floats down the river
A vast plain  57

In the distance a forest, beyond the forest a mountain ra on the mountain a storm, distant cracking of thunder, fai flashes of lightning This is the storm SILAS and JAY are in, and it looks abou day's ride from the middle of the plain The plain, on the other hand, is backing hot, clear blue skies A house sits in the middle of the plain, freshly built, bright yellow pine, oiled paper, not glass, on the window JOHN ROSS stands on the porch of the house he has just bu JOHN looks at the distant storm and shakes his head - he needs the storm to be here, to water his crops He turns to watch a figure walk slowly towards him across plain This is KOTORI, a young, handsome Native American, dresse ‘settler’ shirt and trousers KOTORI carries two large jack rabbits, has a rifle over h shoulder, holds up the rabbits JOHN nods and smiles
Come in Kotori

The Ross house is simply constructed, whitewashed wood walls, paper windows, we may recognise the room from JAY' dream during the flood Now it is furnished - simple furniture mad from pine- a dresser, a table, chairs, a bed The dresser has plates, apples, bottles of milk, glasses There is also a milk churn, other objects of use for dail life far from any store There is a rifle on two nails above the door, a single be the far corner (John's), a door leading to a tiny room wh Rose sleeps - and in the back a small larder full of food utensils, and a back door ROSE is now dressed in trousers and shirt, more practical making her look more grown up, her platted hair makes her more ‘American’  58 50. ROSE ROSS picks up a butter mould and carries it across t room She pauses mid stride as she hears KOTORI approach - she very alert KOTORI enters, ROSE smiles
Kotori She takes the jackrabbits from him and hangs them up on a nail in the back larder JOHN enters and sits down at the table with KOTORI ROSE pours her father a cup of coffee
Turned out nice again ROSE turns
Coffee! ROSE turns back and pours Kotori a coffee
You always ask for coffee and you always spit it out ROSE slowly lifts the top of the butter mould, but the bu has not set and sinks out in a yellow splodge onto the ta
For Gods sake
Language Rose ROSE scrapes up the butter JOHN ROSS (CONT’D) An improvement, stayed on the table They exchange smiles

Meanwhile.. SILAS and JAY are out of the woods and on a grass meadow Their drenched worldly goods are spread out on the grass  51. SILAS sits on his saddle and pours water from his boot JAY wrings out his suit jacket SILAS tries to spit, his dry mouth producing a dribble do his chin
Only thing dry's my mouth SILAS places a soggy cigar in his mouth
My head is killing me SILAS looks at JAY, a testing, intense look
You remember nothing from last night?
I remember Payne.. Then rain SILAS unravels a knotted rope JAY looks at all the wet gear, looks at SILAS, looks at t rope
Give me that rope SILAS throws the rope to JAY

SILAS and JAY are riding across the meadow with a rope ti like a washing line, stretched between the two horses To keep the rope taught they ride about fifteen feet apar All their wet gear is tied to the rope, enabling them to while they ride Both men ride in their long-johns It is both practical and ridiculous SILAS smiles at JAY
Not bad kid First compliment and JAY acts cool but smiles to himself They ride into the sunset, but this is not the end..
PAYNE and his gang appear on the lip of the ridge and sto looking down the hill They are about 500 yards behind JAY and SILAS, who have dismounted and are at the bottom of the hill
I must have been Jay's age when I joined Payne's gang PAYNE’s gang watch as SILAS and JAY stop at the edge of a forest at the bottom of the hill

Those were prosperous times in our trade. When I split, I was lucky to do so with my life This forest is Silverghost, the forest JAY paid SILAS to him too, so they must be close to ROSE now In fact on the far side of the forest is a plain and on t plain sits a house and in that house ROSE, JOHN and KOTOR SILAS turns and looks back up the hill, his fears confirm when he sees PAYNE and his posse at the top of the hill JAY turns to see the posse
What do they want?
They’re bounty hunters. You know what that means?
They hunt bounty? SILAS rummages in his saddlebag and pulls out the wanted poster
They hunt Rose. Daddy. Blood. Money SILAS passes JAY the poster, now sodden from the flood an breaking apart JAY takes a long hard look at the drawing of ROSE and at words DEAD or ALIVE
Wanted .. Dead or ..
Dead or dead, kid  53. JAY takes a BEAT to process
And I'm leading them to her JAY passes the poster back to SILAS
We'll lead them South SILAS shakes his head
There will be others
Others?
Two thousand dollars entices a certain breed of undesirable JAY takes a good hard look at SILAS

And just what breed are you ? SILAS thinks about striking JAY but changes his mind He mounts his horse, looking into the forest Silverghost is a silver birch forest, white trees and gre leaves make it look inviting
Local tribes call this forest ‘the place of spirit trees’, trappers call it ‘Silverghost’ - Legend has it, folks go in, they don’t come out JAY climbs on his pony

Least we may shed the superstitious from PAYNE'S company PAYNE and his company still stand in a row at the top of hill SILAS and JAY, their horses still tied together with the washing line, ride into the forest  60 61 54.
The posse watch SILAS and JAY ride into the forest
Ah God damn you Silas
ROSE is clearing the table, JOHN polishes a horseshoe, KO drinks his coffee A knock at the door JOHN signals ROSE and KOTORI to sit at the table JOHN gets up reaches for the rifle above the door
Who be it ? ROSE signals for KOTORI to move into ROSE’s little bedroo
Victor Self.. Reverend Victor Self Victor has a well spoken English accent, clear and polite JOHN lays the gun down when he hears the word ‘Reverend’

Sorry to bother you, looking for a chap by the name of Parker.. JOHN opens the door to VICTOR VICTOR removes his hat, it is the very same man SILAS saw outside the trading post. Hawklike features, black suit, white dog collar, black hat This is the sharp shooting bounty hunter, VICTOR THE HAWK
James Parker JOHN takes a second to think
No Parkers here minister, won’t you come in JOHN opens the door wide, revealing to VICTOR’S POV, ROSE standing pointing the rifle at him  55.
Sir I thank you, but decline VICTOR nods behind JOHN JOHN turns to see ROSE pointing the gun at VICTOR JOHN lunges at ROSE and grabs the gun
Rose! JOHN ROSS places the gun back up on the nails above the d JOHN ROSS (CONT’D) I'm sorry minister VICTOR smiles
The Good Lord has me on an errand - Bless you and your lovely wife
My daughter
Ah .. Good day sir VICTOR places his hat back on his head, turns and walks o JOHN ROSS walks onto the porch, ROSE follows, they both s staring at VICTOR as he rides off
Heavens above Rose, Scotland is far far away. Nobody knows where we are. Nobody knows who we are
He knows I’m your daughter, I’m called Rose.. And he knows we're here

He was sent by providence. The Lord sensed my wavering faith. Rain is coming JOHN ROSS turns and walks into the house, leaving ROSE on porch to watch VICTOR ride into the distance She knows trouble is coming ROSE turns into the house and shuts the door

JAY and SILAS wind through the silver birch trees of Silverghost The forest is oddly quiet, lacking of bird song or the ch of crickets JAY and SILAS are still in their long johns and have forgotten about the washing line - their clothes now drag along the ground

Thou shall not be afraid of any terror of night, nor for the arrow that flyeth by day. For the pestilence that waketh in Darkness, nor for the sickness that destroyeth in the noon day. (Psalm of David) SILAS responds

“O'er all there hung the shadow of fear, a sense of mystery the spirit daunted, and said as plain as a whisper in the ear, this place is haunted" (page 200 Ambrose Bearce) JAY is taken aback by SILAS sudden poetic knowledge

SILAS, now back in dry trousers, picks up his shirt from washing line rope and shakes the leaves from it. We see t rope still ties the two horses together JAY thinks he sees something move in the trees He wanders into the middle of the clearing A superbly camouflaged figure in between the trees pulls the string of a bow JAY sees the movement but not the figure
Silas .. The trees are moving SILAS turns to look but sees nothing  57.

It’s called a hangover kid. You'll get used to it The figure, a NATIVE AMERICAN, is painted to look like a silver birch tree His bow is drawn and his arrow points at JAY His tribe must be the reason why ‘men come in to Silvergh don’t come out’ The arrow is released with a whizz JAY instinctively raises his hands to cover his face The arrow shoots right through the palm of JAY’s hand and stops an inch before his forehead JAY holds up his hand with the arrow stuck clean through First disbelief, then panic, then pain SILAS wanders over Behind SILAS and JAY, TWO MORE NATIVES dart from the tree and leap on their horses, and gallop past SILAS and JAY SILAS and JAY can only watch The washing line rope is still tied between the horses an drags along the ground The NATIVES pass each side of a tree, the rope snaps tigh around the base of the trunk, bringing the horses to an abrupt stop and trowing the natives into the air One lands with a roll and runs off in disbelief, the othe smacks into a tree and lands with a thud and is knocked o cold SILAS and JAY can’t quite believe what they’ve seen, save the rope.. The NATIVE who fired the arrow at JAY cannot believe it either, not seeing the rope and thinking magic involved, drops his bow and arrow and runs off into the forest JAY grabs SILAS, the arrow in the hand still a slight iss SILAS smiles
Nice catch SILAS snaps the head off the arrow and pulls the remainin arrow out  64 58. JAY yelps in pain SILAS pats JAY on the back
We'll fix you up on the way

In front of the Ross house is a small golden wheatfield , about a hundred meters square In the middle stands a ragged scarecrow At the back of the wheatfield, crouched low, facing the h is VICTOR THE HAWK He opens the long case (SILAS noted at the trading post) in it a long rifle, snug in red velvet, and a neat row of bullets This rifle has a sight attached for distance shooting VICTOR gently lifts the rifle up and looks across the fie About fifty yards to the left of the house JOHN ROSS is building a fence Two posts are up and JOHN ROSS is nailing up a cross spar VICTOR places a bullet in the chamber of the rifle JOHN ROSS lifts the long piece of wood up and hammers in nail, fixing the spar a post The sun is beating down hard VICTOR gages the distance between himself and JOHN ROSS w adjusting the sights and aiming JOHN ROSS, sweating, removes his hat and stares up at the VICTOR is about to pull the trigger, until a sound of the house door opening stops him ROSE and KOTORI appear and run about fifty yards to the r of the house (JOHN ROSS is to the left). There is a washi line with sheets flapping in the breeze, and a pony tied post KOTORI helps ROSE up onto the pony VICTOR looks at ROSE, looks at JOHN ROSS, looks at ROSE

SILAS and JAY wind through the silver birch JAY'’s hand is now wrapped in a dirty bloody rag They ride out of the forest and onto a plain and stop JAY jumps down from his pony and walks out onto the plain In the distance a house, a washing line, a wheatfield, to far to see people, but it is the Ross house, and ROSE is riding, and JOHN ROSS is mending the fence and VICTOR is crouched at the back of the field, but from JAY’s view it looks peaceful and beautiful
I’ve made it SILAS is behind JAY, still on his horse
Are you sure that’s them JAY ignores SILAS and lets out a relieved sigh

Exactly what I imagined As JAY looks towards the house, SILAS dismounts, unhooks rope from the saddle and walks towards JAY SILAS has made a small loop in the end of the rope and he loops it over JAYS hand, pulls the loop tight and grabs J by the scruff of his neck
Hey SILAS drags JAY backwards, JAY struggling, falls to the ground, and is dragged along the ground on his back

Silas! Silas, SILAS, what are you doing.. Stop, no.. Silas! SILAS hauls JAY up against the nearest silver birch tree the edge of the plain, moves behind JAY and passes the ro around the trunk, and ties his hands together JAY is sitting, his back up against the trunk, wriggling spitting with rage SILAS, behind JAY, pulls out his large hunting knife JAY sees the knife, stops wriggling, places his head agai the tree, shuts his eyes  60. JAY thinks Silas is about to slit his throat
Do it quick SILAS looks at JAY incredulously

I ain't going to kill you SILAS cuts the long end of the rope beyond the knot SILAS (CONT’D) I’m keeping you alive. We don’t have a gun between us SILAS walks around and sits in front of JAY, rubs the tre above JAY'S head and the white powder of the silver birch rubs off onto SILAS’S hand SILAS grabs the back of JAY’S head
Hold still SILAS rubs the white powder over JAY’s face
What is this!
Stops the sun burning you up JAY rages
I'll protect Rose or die trying SILAS turns and walks to his horse
That’s what I’m afraid of

Lay a finger on her and I’11l kill you SILAS ignores JAY, grabs the reins of JAY'S horse, climbs onto his horse JAY throws himself into a rage JAY wriggles, dribbles Begins to rub the rope up and down the back of the tree  66 67 68 69 61. SILAS gallops off with both horses across the plain in th direction of the Ross house

ROSE and KOTORI walk slowly back to the house VICTOR keeps them in the sights of his rifle, his finger the trigger .-But first his view is blocked by the washing line, then the scarecrow, then ROSE and KOTORI enter the house and s the door VICTOR lowers his rifle VICTOR looks back towards JOHN ROSS and lifts his rifle a has JOHN ROSS in his sights again JOHN ROSS picks up a couple of nails from a little wooden box, places one nail between his teeth and begins to hamm the other one into the fence VICTOR steadies himself, holds his breath and his rifle stills A nail is hammered into wood Sweat drips from the rim of JOHN ROSS’s hat As the hammer strikes the head of the nail, VICTOR pulls trigger, a loud bang echoes across the plain JOHN ROSS’S hammer falls to the ground
Inside the house ROSE hears the bang She stops what she’s doing and listens, the echo of the gunshot still audible
JAY frantically rubbing, also hears the shot and freezes
VICTOR lowers his gun, and in the distance, JOHN ROSS fal to the ground  70 71 72 73 74 75 62.
SILAS gallops fast towards the house, JAY’s horse gallopi by his side
JOHN ROSS lies dead - blood in the grass, ROSE can be hea shouting (from screen right) inside the house
Dadda!! Da!!
JAY rubs rope against tree, faster than ever and it is beginning to fray
SILAS gallops across the plain
VICTOR, now standing, puts his jacket on, brushes himself down, looking towards the house
